title: Abscess (pyogenic): Pyogenic, subacute, unilocular, with contained rupture
clinical_presentation: 64 year old African American man with Ig A Kappa monoclonal gammopathy who presented with abdominal pain and tenderness.

diagnosis.information:
Author: Claudia Sadro, MD

 

Synonyms

Bacterial liver abscess

Epidemiology

  • Incidence of pyogenic liver abscess is decreasing due to improved therapies for abdominal infections such as appendicitis, diverticulitis and inflammatory bowel disease
  • Increased risk of infection in patients with biliary obstruction or biliary procedures, immune compromise or diabetes

Etiology

  • Portal seeding from abdominal infections such as appendicitis, diverticulitis or inflammatory bowel disease
  • Ascending biliary infection from obstruction (benign or malignant), stenting or other biliary procedures
  • Direct spread of infection from acute cholecystitis
  • Hematogenous spread in patients with intravenous drug use or bacterial endocarditis
  • Cryptogenic liver abscess occurs with no predisposing cause and is reported to occur in 15-53% of patients
  • Increased risk with immune compromise and diabetes

 

Pathology

Subtypes
 

- Cryptogenic and abscesses that occur secondary to abdominal infection:

  • Tend to be solitary
  • Enter the liver through the portal venous system
  • Tend to occur in the posterior right lobe
     

- Abscesses from ascending biliary infection:

  • Tend to be multifocal
  • Central in location and often in a hepatic segment or lobe
     

- Abscesses that occur from direct spread from acute cholecystitis are central adjacent to the gallbladder

- Abscesses that occur due to hematogenous spread in patients with intravenous drug use or infective endocarditis:

  • Multiple (see candida)
  • Small
  • May also infect the spleen
     

Microscopic

  • Center of abscess is composed of bacteria and pus
  • Destruction of hepatic parenchyma with surrounding inflammatory reaction
  • Most pyogenic liver abscesses are polymicrobial and the most common organism isolated is Escherchia coli.  Abscesses due to hematogenous dissemination are usually due to Staphylococcus

 

Imaging

General

  • Cavities that may contain gas
  • Clearly defined wall 
  • Often with perifocal edema

Subtypes

  • Cryptogenic abscess and liver abscess secondary to abdominal infection are usually due to coliforms
  • Abscesses from ascending biliary infection:

- Microabscesses are centrally located and often localized to a segment or lobe of the liver
- Often biliary obstruction with enhancement of the bile ducts

  • Abscesses from hematogenous dissemination

- Microabscesses are randomly distributed throughout the liver
- Involvement of the spleen possible
- When <1 cm they may completely enhance and resemble flash filling hemangiomas

  • Abscesses from direct spread of acute cholecystitis are situated adjacent to an inflamed gallbladder.  Discontinuity of the gall bladder wall possible

CT

Acute

Cluster of closely opposed small rim enhancing cavities < 2 cm (“cluster sign”)

Subacute

  • Microcavities coalesce into a unilocular cavity
  • Enhancing wall
  • Contains fluid and possibly gas
  • Perilesional edema that is low density (classic “double target sign”)
  • Transient hepatic attenuation differences (THAD) are possible peripheral to the abscess due to reduced venous flow from inflammation in portal triads and compensatory increased hepatic arterial flow

MR

Acute

Cluster of closely opposed small rim enhancing cavities that are hypointense on T1 and hyperintense on T2

Subacute

  • Microcavities coalesce into a unilocular cavity
  • Enhancing wall
  • Contains fluid that is hypointense on T1 and hyperintense on T2
  • Internal gas is low signal intensity on all sequences.
  • Perilesional edema peripheral to enhancing wall is hyperintense on T2
  • Transient hepatic intensity differences (THID) are possible peripheral to the abscess

US

Appearance is variable, may be hypo-, hyperechoic or mixed echogenicity

Acute

  • Echogenicity similar to liver
  • Ill defined
  • Regional distortion of hepatic parenchyma with posterior acoustic enhancement
  • Cluster of microabscesses (<2cm) with decreased echogenicity centrally with echogenic rims with posterior acoustic enhancement possible

Subacute

  • Microabscesses coalesce into a unilocular cavity with irregular walls, a hypoechoic liquefied center with debris and posterior acoustic enhancement.
  • Internal gas presents as areas of increased echogenicity with reverberation artifact.
  • Abscess wall and surrounding parenchyma may be hyperemic with increased vascularity on color doppler

 

Differential Diagnosis

Cryptogenic liver abscess and liver abscess due to abdominal infection may resemble

  • Cystic or necrotic metastases
  • Hemorrhagic cyst
  • Amebic abscess
  • Echinococcus granulosus (hydatid)
  • Biliary cystadenoma
     

Liver abscesses due to ascending cholangitis and hematogenous dissemination may resemble

  • Candidiasis
  • Metastases
  • Lymphoma
  • Flash filling hemangiomas (if <1 cm)

 

Complications

  • Contained rupture with subcapsular abscess
  • Intraperitoneal rupture with peritonitis

 

Treatment

Percutaneous drainage when > 5 cm, intravenous antibiotics and treatment of the offending cause

ctmodality.specific_diagnosis: Unilocular, with perifocal edema and contained perforation
ctmodality.imaging_findings: Pyogenic liver abscess, confirmed on exploratory laparotomy, which revealed gram positive cocci. No hepatic extramedullary disease. CT shows a unilocular subacute liver abscess in segment 4 of the left lobe with a thin capsule, surrounding hypodense edema and focal contained rupture superiorly (see coronal reconstruction). Mild pericardial effusion. Courtesy Tarun Pandey, MD, Hemendra Shah, MD, University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences, AK, USA.
